Factor Theorem

Building on the division process from the previous page, we have seen that we can take any polynomial \(P(x)\) and number \(a\) and write \[ P(x) = (x-a)Q(x) +  r, \] where \(Q(x)\) is a polynomial with degree less than the degree of \(P(x)\), and \(r\) is a number. For example, \[ \frac{x^2+x-10}{x-3} = x+4 + \frac{2}{x-3} \] so multiplying throughout by \(x-3\), we get \[ x^2+x-10 = (x-3)(x+4) + 2 \] i.e. we have found \(Q(x)=x+4\) and \(r=2\).

Using this observation, we can establish two theorems which are useful when working with polynomials - the factor and remainder theorems.


Theorem

\(x-a\) is a factor of \(P(x)\) if and only if \(P(a)=0\).

Proof

Because this is an "if and only if" statement, we need to prove both directions, (we will talk more about this in week 3).

  • If \(P(a)=0\) then \[ \begin{eqnarray} P(x) &=& (x-a)Q(x)+P(a) \\ &=& (x-a)Q(x). \end{eqnarray} \] So we have written \(P(x)\) as a product of \(x-a\) and another polynomial, meaning \(x-a\) is a factor of \(P(x)\).
  • If \(x-a\) is a factor of \(P(x)\), this means we can write \(P(x)=(x-a)Q(x)\) for some polynomial \(Q(x)\). Using this expression, \(P(a)=(a-a)Q(a)=0\times Q(a)=0\).

Since we have proved both directions, this completes the proof.


For the example above, the fact that \(P(-4)=2\) tells us that \(x+4\) is not a factor of \(P(x)\).
